title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Minority Leader of the House. Appointments include academic researchers, data experts, program administrators, and individuals with expertise in database management and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders. Each leader appoints three members with expertise in academic research, data analysis, program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints members with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The President and Speaker of the House select the chairperson and co-chairperson. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members of the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses for official duties. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking members serve without pay and receive travel expenses for official duties. The duties of the Commission are outlined in Section 4. The Commission will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating data for program evaluation and incorporating outcomes measurement into program design. Consideration will be given to creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data. The Commission will study creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, considering relevant administrative datasets, survey data linkages, legal barriers, data-sharing infrastructure, funding, access for researchers, limitations on data use, and information protection. The Commission will study access to data for qualified researchers and officials, limitations on data use, privacy protection, using data for program improvement, and incentives for interagency data sharing. The Commission will submit a report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and Congress within 15 months of the majority vote. The Commission will submit a report on access to administrative data for qualified researchers and officials, data use limitations, privacy protection, program improvement, and interagency data sharing incentives within 15 months of the majority vote. The report will include findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative actions based on the study results. The term "administrative data" refers to information generated or collected by an agency for Federal programs, including customer service, efficiency, milestone, outcome, and performance measures. The Commission's operation and powers are outlined in Section 5. The Commission shall receive administrative assistance from various agencies, hold meetings within 30 days of majority appointment, and establish rules of procedure with majority approval. The Commission, with majority approval, will establish rules of procedure including a quorum requirement. It may hold hearings, contract with government and private agencies, use the United States mails, accept gifts, and have the Director of the Census contract with the Census Bureau and NAPA, subject to appropriations. The Commission may accept gifts or donations of services or property. The Director of the Census can contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to administer the Commission, with funding not to exceed $2,000,000 from principal statistical agencies. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson and co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff. The Commission may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 7. TERMINATION. The Commission shall terminate within 18 months of enactment.
